Dual y-axis graphing functions

Source: R/sec_axes_rescale.R
dual_y_axis.Rd

ggplot2, by design, makes it rather difficult to create graphs where the primary and secondary y-axis are on different scales. Hadley Wickham claims this is to prevent people from abusing secondary y-axis to show dodgy correlations (investment banking-style). However, sometimes they have valid uses and the following functions enable this with as little fiddliness as possible.

Usage

sec_rescale_inv(values, scale = 1, shift = 0)

sec_rescale(values, scale = sec_axis_scale, shift = sec_axis_shift)

Arguments

values

Vector of data that would normally be passed as the y aesthetic in the graph.

scale

Numeric. Multiplicative factor that rescales the axis. For example, if the scale was originally 0 to 50, then scale = 0.1 would rescale this to 0 to 5.

shift

Numeric. Moves the axis up and down. For example, if the scale was 0 to 5, shift = 5 moves the secondary scale down by 5 units to -5 to 0.

Details

sec_rescale_inv is used in the geom that will be displayed on the secondary axis. sec_rescale is used in the sec_axis argument of scale_y_continuous_e61.

See the examples for how to use the two functions to manipulate the secondary axis. Trial and error will be needed to select appropriate scale and shift values.

Examples


library(ggplot2)
data <- data.frame(x = 1:5, y1 = 1:5 * 10, y2 = 5:1 - 5)

ggplot(data, aes(x)) +
  geom_col(aes(y = y1)) +
  geom_point(aes(y = sec_rescale_inv(y2, scale = 0.1, shift = 5))) +
  # Some extra arguments are required to correctly format the secondary axis:
  # Set rescaled_sec = TRUE in scale_y_continuous_e61() to format the breaks correctly.
  # The secondary y-axis label (name = "%") needs to be explicitly specified otherwise it will not appear.
  scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 60, 10), sec_axis = sec_axis(~sec_rescale(.), name = "%"), rescale_sec = TRUE) +
  theme_e61() +
  labs_e61(y = "%")
#> Error in sec_rescale(breaks): object 'sec_axis_scale' not found
